SubTopics: Create and evaluate solutions to increase voter participation. Evaluate their role in government at the local, state, tribal, and federal levels.
Content: Which the following initiatives could be implemented at the local government level to increase voter participation?

A.Choice: make election day a national holiday

B.Choice: create a state automatic voter registration system

C.Choice: set up a nonprofit organization to provide free transportation to the polls

D.Choice: authorize a school district to pre-register sixteen- and seventeen-year-olds

SubTopics: Analyze the intended purpose of a specific primary or secondary source.
Content: Read the information in the box.

:box:Some Features of the Articles of Confederation, 1781

• Each state retains any powers not expressly listed in the Articles.
• The nation is a “league of friendship,” whose states will help protect each other from attacks.
• People can travel freely among the states.
• Each state gets one vote in Congress.
• The central government is responsible for international relations.
• States must maintain a militia but cannot have a standing army.
• States will raise their own money to send to the central government.
Based on the information in the box, what was the intended purpose of the Articles of Confederation?

A.Choice: to create a uniform code of laws that all states would adhere to and to create a national culture

B.Choice: to create a plan of governing the nation that would enforce national laws and collect necessary taxes

C.Choice: to create a plan of government that would make peace treaties with international powers and ensure national security

D.Choice: to create a nation where states have most of the power and work together to avoid a too-powerful central government

SubTopics: Evaluate the purpose for which a technology is created and analyze the consequences (intended and unintended) to different cultures.
Content: Look at the diagram.
problems/WIG10SS/media/3a.jpg
Based on the information in the diagram, which conclusion can BEST be drawn?

A.Choice: Industrialists in the region have a stronger workforce.

B.Choice: The region is still struggling with near-famine conditions.

C.Choice: Rice farmers in the region have a lower standard of living.

D.Choice: The region is dependent on rice production and consumption.

SubTopics: Analyze the evolution of the global economy to its present state and the role it plays in the economic development of world regions. Analyze the role of supranational organizations (e.g., NAFTA, NATO, UN).
Content: Why was the United Nations founded?

SubTopics: Analyze the evolution of the global economy to its present state and the role it plays in the economic development of world regions. Analyze the role of supranational organizations (e.g., NAFTA, NATO, UN).
Content: The United States is a founding member of the United Nations and a member of many other international organizations. What is the MAIN reason the United States joins international organizations such as the United Nations?

A.Choice: Membership allows the United States to control its allies.

Key.Rationale: The United States is a leader in the organizations but does not control the actions of other member nations.

B.Choice: Membership helps the United States to protect its interests.

C.Choice: Membership helps U.S. citizens find work in other countries.

Key.Rationale: Job opportunities are not the main reason for U.S. membership in international organizations.

D.Choice: Membership grants U.S. citizens increased travel opportunities.

Key.Rationale: Travel is not the main reason for U.S. membership in international organizations.

SubTopics: Analyze the means by and extent to which groups and institutions can influence people, events, and cultures in both historical and contemporary settings. Become critically aware of ethnocentrism, its manifestations, and consequences in a world that is increasingly interconnected.
Content: In February 1938, a Works Progress Administration writer interviewed Roland Damiani, an Italian immigrant. Read the excerpt from the interview.

:box:My fellow Italians have elected me to many positions, because they appreciate learning and wish themselves to become true Americans.

You are right. The children of Italian immigrants wish most of all to become Americans. They make haste to adopt the American customs and speech. In fact they worry and grieve their parents, who cannot understand or keep pace with them. It is not a little tragic sometimes, —this conflict between the children and their elders.

	—Library of Congress, Manuscript Division, WPA Federal Writers' Project Collection
Which action MOST likely contributed to the assimilation of immigrant children into American culture?

Key.Rationale: The passage describes how the children of immigrants wish to become American and how they have learned the language and customs of their new country. This desire to become American and their knowledge of the language and customs most likely came from attending American schools.
This choice would have had some influence, but it would not be as great as attending public school.
This choice describes an action that would help them retain old customs, not adopt American customs.
This choice describes an action that would help them retain old customs, not adopt American customs.

SubTopics: Evaluate how incentives determine what is produced and distributed in a competitive market system.
Content: Use the information in the graph to answer the question.
problems/WIG10SS/media/7a.jpg
How could the data in the graph for the years 2005–2010 affect decisions made by car manufacturers?

A.Choice: Manufacturers would reduce production levels on all vehicles when fuel costs are high.

B.Choice: Manufacturers would want to include the latest technology features to attract new customers.

C.Choice: Manufacturers would emphasize increased safety features to convince consumers to purchase their products.

D.Choice: Manufacturers would anticipate consumer demand for fuel-efficient vehicles to assure a profitable business.

SubTopics: Evaluate the intended and unintended costs and benefits (i.e., externalities) of government policies to improve market outcomes and standards of living. Analyze the effectiveness of how people, government policies, and economic systems have attempted to address income inequality and working conditions both now and in the past.
Content: Look at the headline.
problems/WIG10SS/media/8a.jpg
Why would Congress take this action?

Key.Rationale: An investment in infrastructure will not affect which products people buy.

Congress will increase spending in order to promote economic growth. Investments in infrastructure will give many people jobs. People with jobs have money to spend on goods and services, which will help the economy grow.
Investing in the economy is expanding the power of the government, not limiting it.

D.Choice: to reduce costs of delivery services

Key.Rationale: New bridges and roads will help goods get from one place to another faster and reduce costs, but it is not why Congress would take the action described in the headline.

SubTopics: Evaluate how the historical context influenced the process or nature of the continuity or change that took place.
Content: Read the information in the table.
problems/WIG10SS/media/9a.jpg
Which of the following historical events MOST likely had the greatest impact on the numbers of immigrants entering the United States?

A.Choice: In 1882, Congress passed the Chinese Exclusion Act.

SubTopics: Analyze the intentional and unintentional spatial consequences of human actions on the environment at the local, state, tribal, regional, country, and world levels.
Content: Read the information in the box.

:box:In the mid-1800s, Europeans learned of the many resources of Africa. From 1880 until 1914, European countries competed to claim parts of Africa. This became known as “The Scramble for Africa.” In 1885, fourteen European nations met to divide up the continent. This division paid little attention to natural boundaries or cultural borders. After World War II, most European nations gave up their land in Africa and the countries became independent. As the European powers left the continent, old tribal conflicts resurfaced. Many civil wars were fought and new nations were created.
Which conclusion can BEST be drawn based on the information in the box?

A.Choice: The division of Africa by European leaders led to conflict.

Key.Rationale: The passage describes how political boundaries created by European states led to conflict in Africa.

B.Choice: Many Africans embraced being ruled by European leaders.

Key.Rationale: This choice describes a conclusion that is not supported by the passage.

C.Choice: African nations prospered under the guidance of European leaders.

Key.Rationale: This choice describes a conclusion that is not supported by the passage.

D.Choice: The division of Africa by European leaders protected its natural resources.

Key.Rationale: This choice describes a conclusion that is not supported by the passage.

SubTopics: Evaluate how values and beliefs (e.g., economic freedom, economic efficiency, equity, full employment, price stability, security, efficiency and growth) help to form different types of economic systems and analyze how they have been affected by specific political and social systems and important events. Analyze how the allocation of resources can impact the distribution of wealth and income equality or inequality.
Content: Read the information in the chart.
problems/WIG10SS/media/11a.jpg
Based on the information in the chart, which action would likely occur ONLY in an economy based on capitalism?

A.Choice: The government funds and operates public utilities.

Key.Rationale: This choice describes a characteristic of a socialist system.

B.Choice: The government sets and implements economic goals.

Key.Rationale: This choice describes a characteristic of a socialist system.

C.Choice: Individuals are guaranteed a minimum standard of living.

Key.Rationale: This choice describes a characteristic of a socialist system.

D.Choice: Individuals are able to move between economic classes.

Key.Rationale: Only a system that practices capitalism allows people to move between economic classes. In a capitalist economy, people who work hard and possess the right skills have the ability to improve their social standing.

SubTopics: Analyze how the POV of the author can influence the content and intent of a primary or secondary source and identify whose voices may be left out.
Content: Albert Beveridge was a senator from Indiana from 1899 to 1911. He became known for his support of U.S. territorial expansion, also known as imperialism. Read the excerpt from one of his senatorial campaign speeches.

:box:Shall we avail ourselves of new sources of supply of what we do not raise or make, so that what are luxuries to-day will be necessities to-morrow? ... To-day, we are raising more than we can consume. To-day, we are making more than we can use. Therefore, we must find ... new occupation for our capital, new work for our labor.

	—from “March of the Flag,” Albert Beveridge, 1898
Based on the excerpt, what did Beveridge MOST likely believe was the main advantage of continued American imperialism?

A.Choice: It would give U.S. citizens more opportunities to travel to other countries.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by the excerpt, but it is a reasons for or effects of American imperialism.

B.Choice: It would encourage U.S. citizens to adapt to new types of jobs and products.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by the excerpt, but it is a reasons for or effects of American imperialism.

C.Choice: It would provide new resources and markets to strengthen U.S. businesses.

Key.Rationale: Beveridge believed that the United States should increase its territories in order to find new markets for its products.

D.Choice: It would allow people in developing nations to benefit from U.S. education practices.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by the excerpt, but it is a reasons for or effects of American imperialism.

SubTopics: Analyze how constitutionalism attempts to preserve fundamental societal values, protects individual freedoms and rights, promotes the general welfare, and responds to changing circumstances and beliefs by defining and limiting the powers of government. Analyze sources of governmental authority.
Content: Read the information in the box.

:box:To make all Laws which shall be necessary and proper for carrying into Execution the foregoing Powers, and all other Powers vested by this Constitution in the Government of the United States, or in any Department or Officer thereof.

	—from Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution

Over time, this portion of the U.S. Constitution became known as the elastic clause because it allowed Congress to stretch its powers. Some examples of Congress using this power include creating the national bank, placing regulations on nuclear power plants, and developing a space program.
Which statement BEST describes how this clause has been used to address changing circumstances?

A.Choice: It allows Congress to raise taxes to provide courts and lawyers to citizens.

B.Choice: It allows Congress to revise laws to increase citizen participation in government.

C.Choice: It allows Congress to take action on topics not expressly listed in the Constitution.

D.Choice: It allows Congress to grant the states powers not expressly listed in the Constitution.

SubTopics: Evaluate population policies by analyzing how governments affect population change. Analyze population compositions (e.g., age, gender, ethnicity) and the different implications each has on countries or regions throughout the world.
Content: Read the information in the box.
:box:China is trying to modernize its population. To accomplish this, the government wants to move 70% of the country's population into cities by 2025.
Based on the information in the box, which statement describes what is MOST likely to occur?

A.Choice: Air and water pollution will worsen in urban areas.

Key.Rationale: As more people move to urban areas, more pollution is produced.

B.Choice: More people will be able to find work in agriculture.

Key.Rationale: An increase in urban residents will reduce the number of people who work in agriculture.

C.Choice: Rural areas will experience a decrease in soil fertility.

Key.Rationale: The change in population will not affect the quality of soil in rural areas, but it is a reason why people leave these areas and move to cities.

D.Choice: The number of small businesses and family-owned farms will increase.

Key.Rationale: The change in population will most likely decrease the number of small farms and businesses in the area.

SubTopics: Critique the struggle for suffrage and citizenship since the founding period. Analyze the constitutional tension between protecting individual rights and promoting the general welfare and security of the country, as well as between majority rule and minority rights. Assess the impact of individuals, groups, and movements on the development of civil rights for different groups.
Content: Read the information in the boxes.

:box:The Congress shall have Power ... To declare war.

	—from Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution

:box:Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, That the Congress approves and supports the determination of the President, as Commander in Chief, to take all necessary measures to repel any armed attack against the forces of the United States and to prevent further aggression.

	—from the Tonkin Gulf Resolution, 1964
What was an effect of the Tonkin Gulf Resolution?

A.Choice: It limited the effectiveness of the legislature.

Key.Rationale: The legislature was not made any less effective by this resolution, but its power was reduced.

B.Choice: It increased the powers of the executive branch.

Key.Rationale: The Tonkin Gulf Resolution increased the powers of the executive branch. Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution gave Congress the power to declare war. The Tonkin Gulf Resolution gave the president the power to use all means necessary if the United States is attacked.

C.Choice: It showed the weaknesses of having multiple branches of government.

Key.Rationale: The information shows the branches working together.

D.Choice: It allowed the military to operate without the approval of elected leaders.

Key.Rationale: Neither the excerpt from the U.S. Constitution nor the Tonkin Gulf Resolution allowed the U.S. military to act on its own accord.

SubTopics: Evaluate the purpose for which a technology is created and analyze the consequences (intended and unintended) to different cultures.
Content: Look at the image and read the information about an important invention of the late nineteenth century.
problems/WIG10SS/media/16a.jpg

:box:This innovation has relation to means of preventing cattle from breaking through wire fences, and it consists in combining, with the twisted fence wires.

	— Joseph F. Glidden, Patent for Barbed Wire, 1873

:box:Many scholars credit this invention with allowing the settlement of the American West. Barbed wire was the first wire technology capable of restraining cattle. It grew in popularity because it was cheaper and easier to use than other fencing options available at the time. Barbed wire also helped Western settlers stake their claim to land. Typically, notification of land purchases and holdings were published in the newspaper. New landowners were able to solidify their claim by surrounding the area in barbed wire.
How did the invention and use of barbed wire affect the Native Americans living on the Plains during the 1800s?

A.Choice: It helped Native Americans protect sacred sites.

B.Choice: It helped Native Americans find more resources.

C.Choice: It limited the areas in which Native Americans could hunt.

D.Choice: It limited the resources Native Americans used to build new shelters.

SubTopics: Evaluate the work and actions of historically significant people and their contributions to the founding principles of the United States. Analyze the foundational ideas of United States government that are embedded in founding era documents. Analyze landmark Supreme Court decisions regarding how the Constitution and the Bill of Rights limit the government, protect individual rights, support the principle of majority rule while protecting the rights of the minority, and promotes the general welfare. Analyze the meaning and importance of rights in the Wisconsin Constitution, and compare or contrast to the United States Constitution.
Content: Read the list of some of the rights outlined in Article I of the Wisconsin Constitution.

:box:• Equality; inherent rights
• Slavery prohibited
• Free speech; libel
• Right to assemble and petition
• Trial by jury; verdict in civil cases
• Equal property rights for aliens and citizens
• Rights of suitors
• Maintenance of free government
• Transportation of school children
• Use of school buildings
• Right to keep and bear arms
• Right to fish, hunt, trap, and take game
:ibox:Answer Part A and Part B for this question.
Which statement BEST describes why some of the rights in this list are similar to the rights outlined in the Bill of Rights?

A.Choice: The federal government dictates laws to the states.

B.Choice: Residents of Wisconsin are also citizens of the United States.

C.Choice: The laws of the federal government are stronger than the laws of the states.

D.Choice: People in the United States are guaranteed the same rights as the people of Wisconsin.

Content: Which statement BEST describes why some of the rights in this list are different from the rights outlined in the Bill of Rights?

A.Choice: These rights are important to the residents of Wisconsin.

B.Choice: These rights will eventually be extended to citizens in other states.

C.Choice: The state wants to use these legal protections to attract new residents.

D.Choice: The people of Wisconsin need more protections than citizens of other states need.
